titleproper.value:
Guide to the Stanford White Commemorative Stamp Special Collection 
                    <lb/>
                    <date>1979-1982 </date>
                    <lb/>
                    <num>MC 6</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Bayrd Still. Online finding aid created by Julianna Monjeau.

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2016-06-08T11:14-0400</date>

unittitle.value: Stanford White Commemorative Stamp Special Collection

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: Stanford White, a partner of the architectural firm McKim, Mead, & White (1879-1906), designed several buildings of the University Heights campus of New York University, including the Gould Memorial Library (c. 1895). The campus is now part of the Bronx Community College of the City University of New York. The United States Postal Service selected Stanford White to be one of four architects honored in a block of stamps issued in 1979 in commemoration of American architecture. The Gould Memorial Library was selected as the structure to represent the work of Stanford White.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: Identification of item, date (if known); Stanford White Commemorative Stamp Special Collection; MC 6; box number; folder number; New York University Archives, New York University Libraries.

Stanford White maintained connections with New York University for most of his career. In 1881, he was awarded an honorary Master of Arts degree. In 1892, as Chancellor MacCracken and the University Council were contemplating the move of the undergraduate college to the Heights from Washington Square, they asked Stanford White to estimate the cost of removing the Gothic University Building on the Square to the Heights. Rather than transplant the old building in the Heights, White instead designed a new NYU campus in what became University Heights. The realization of White's plan moved progressively to fruition from the late 1890's into the early 20th century. With a generous gift from Helen Gould, daughter of famed railroad tycoon Jay Gould, making the Gould Memorial Library possible, ground was broken on the occasion of the formal opening of the Heights Campus on October 19, 1895.

This collection consists of correspondence, press releases, newspaper clippings, first day covers, an album of stamps, and photographs pertaining to the selection and publication of Stanford White's Gould Memorial Library in the American Architecture Stamp series.
